page.title: 03DRAINAGE OF WOODSPRING COAST
page.content: The low_lying nature of the landscape means that it is in constant danger of flooding from surface land water and sea water at times of high tide and storm.In both villages the surface water drains into the rhines which in turn flow into the Congresbury Yeo and thence into the sea .The flow is governed by a series of sluices, operated electronically, managed by the Wessex Water Board.The sluices allow the fresh water to escape when necessary but prevent the salt tidal water from getting into the waterways to the detriment of plants and wildlife. When ditches are filled in for road widening or building great care is taken to pipe them adequately to ensure the proper flow of water. Experience has shown that the original rhine diggers were wise men who understood the nature of the land.
